Let's Get Started

Markup first, style second

  • Mark things up semantically and the styles should follow.
  • In general, text should not live naked inside a <div> unless you're doing something 1%-ish.

Occupy stylesheet

  • The default styles should work for the 99% of elements on your page.
  • If an element is truly part of the 1%, wearing a monocle and standing on a yacht, use modifier classes and page-specific styles.

Blocks that fit together

  • Padding (top, right, left) happens on wrappers.
  • Margin (bottom) happens on block-level content.
  • like this

Layout

OOCSS Grids are used to break any space into fractions, they can be nested and stacked. A unit can contain another line or it can contain other objects directly. Grids control width, content controls height.

.line is a row. .unit is a column.

DEPRECATED: .gutter-left, .gutter-right (resulted in uneven width of lastUnit)

See also: https://github.com/stubbornella/oocss/wiki/Grids 

<div class="line">
	<div class="unit size1of3">	
		...first column...
	</div>	
	<div class="unit size1of3">	
		...second column...
	</div>
	<div class="lastUnit">	
		...third column...
	</div>
</div>
.unit .size1of5
.unit .size1of5
.unit .size1of5
.unit .size1of5
.lastUnit
.unit .size1of4
.unit .size1of4
.unit .size1of4
.lastUnit
.unit .size1of3
.unit .size1of3
.lastUnit
.unit .size1of7
.unit .size4of7
.lastUnit
.unit .size1of5
.lastUnit
.unit .size3of5
.lastUnit
.unit .size3of4
.lastUnit

For gutters, use .line-gutters instead of .line. Gutters are applied as padding on the right of each .unit

.unit .size1of4
.unit .size1of4
.unit .size1of4
.lastUnit

You can create a new .line inside any .unit or .lastUnit.

.unit .size1of2
.unit .size1of2
.lastUnit
.lastUnit
--- heading: Box and sections ---

.doc-box is the main box of the page. 99% of the time, there should be only one.

Optionally, your box can be divided into columns by using the standard grid, if you so desire. Do not use gutters here.

Next, a "section" of content is created by adding .doc-content . Simple boxes may have only one section.

My first document box

Let's start with some prose. Proident high life food truck, four loko accusamus esse photo booth single-origin coffee tattooed laborum mollit. 3 wolf moon gentrify organic +1 scenester put a bird on it, photo booth nisi.

List of things

  • Leggings Austin minim readymade aliquip, elit voluptate aesthetic. Cosby sweater organic single-origin coffee aliquip adipisicing, food truck american apparel. Aesthetic high life qui retro cliche.

  • Leggings Austin minim readymade aliquip, elit voluptate aesthetic. Cosby sweater organic single-origin coffee aliquip adipisicing, food truck american apparel. Aesthetic high life qui retro cliche.

 
		<div class="doc-box">
			<div class="doc-content">
				<h1>My first document box</h1>
				<p>Let's start with some prose...</p>
			</div>
			<div class="doc-content">
				<h2>List of things</h2>
				<ul class="dividedList">
					<li>
						<p>Leggings Austin minim...</p>
					</li>
					<li>
						<p>Leggings Austin minim...</p>
					</li>
				</ul>	
			</div>
		</div>
--- heading: Doc content types ---

What it is

.doc-content-notice

.doc-content-into

.doc-content-outof

This is here to notify you

Biodiesel vinyl leggings trust fund, proident williamsburg keytar in blog dolore sustainable. Veniam fanny pack cupidatat, tempor nesciunt master cleanse cillum do vegan duis brooklyn minim cliche mollit.

Some normal page

Biodiesel vinyl leggings trust fund, proident williamsburg keytar in blog dolore sustainable. Veniam fanny pack cupidatat, tempor nesciunt master cleanse cillum do vegan duis brooklyn minim cliche mollit. Lomo reprehenderit wolf pariatur lo-fi id sartorial yr, laborum consequat quinoa DIY eu.

Notice how the first box flows into this one. Cool, huh? Biodiesel vinyl leggings trust fund, proident williamsburg keytar in blog dolore sustainable. Veniam fanny pack cupidatat, tempor nesciunt master cleanse cillum do vegan duis brooklyn minim cliche mollit. Lomo reprehenderit wolf pariatur lo-fi id sartorial yr, laborum consequat quinoa DIY eu.

Lists

It's a simple list with nothing but padding. Good for very simple items.

.paddedList

Simple .paddedList

  • List items are divided...

  • This doesn't need any special "first" or "last" classes

  • You can subdivide these list items into columns with the standard grid, if you like

 <div class="doc-box">
	<div class="doc-content">
		<h3>Simple <code>.paddedList</code></h3>
		<ul class="paddedList">
			<li><p>List items are divided...</p></li>
			<li><p>This doesn't need any special 
				"first" or "last" classes</p>
			</li>
			<li><p>You can subdivide these list items into columns 
				with the standard grid, if you like</p>
			</li>
		</ul>
	</div>
</div>

This is the most common list. If you're listing things, chances are, this is the one you want.

.dividedList

A normal dividedList

  • Sally Smeetup

    Lists are the backbone of society.

  • Sally Smeetup

    Lists are the backbone of society.

  • Sally Smeetup

    Lists are the backbone of society.

 <div class="doc-box">
	<div class="doc-content">
		<h3>A normal dividedList</h3>
		<ul class="dividedList">
		
			<li>
				<div class="figureset">
					<div class="figureset-figure">
						<a href=""><img src="http://placekitten.com/40/40" /></a>
					</div>
					<div class="figureset-description">
						<h4><a href="">Sally Smeetup</a></h4>
						<p>Lists are the backbone of society.</p>
					</div>
				</div>
			</li>
		
			<li>
				<div class="figureset">
					<div class="figureset-figure">
						<a href=""><img src="http://placekitten.com/40/40" /></a>
					</div>
					<div class="figureset-description">
						<h4><a href="">Sally Smeetup</a></h4>
						<p>Lists are the backbone of society.</p>
					</div>
				</div>
			</li>
		
			<li>
				<div class="figureset">
					<div class="figureset-figure">
						<a href=""><img src="http://placekitten.com/40/40" /></a>
					</div>
					<div class="figureset-description">
						<h4><a href="">Sally Smeetup</a></h4>
						<p>Lists are the backbone of society.</p>
					</div>
				</div>
			</li>
		
		</ul>
	</div>
</div>

For lists with particularly complex items (looking at you, group home), you can omit the .doc-contentand use a .sectionList. The list items then span the box and behave as if each were its own .doc-content

.sectionList

A full-width .sectionList

Forms

Buttons

As a rule, buttons are for actions, not navigation. This style applies to 

<input type="submit" />, <button>
, and anything with the class .button.

The default is a simple gray button. There is also red .primary class for "do this one thing" actions.

For side-by-side inputs and buttons, you'll probably want something a little smaller than the default button. For this, you can use the .small class.

Default buttons

Small inline button next to an input (.small.inline)

Default stacked forms

To group related label & input pairs, put them in a fieldset. Use OOCSS grids to divide into columns if needed.

Where are you? 
 <form>
	<label for="name">Name</label>
	<input id="name" type="text">

	<label for="color">Favorite color</label>
	<select name="color">
		<option>Midnight Saffron</option>
		<option>Seabreeze Brown</option>
		<option>Fragrant Forest Ochre</option>
	</select>

	<fieldset class="line-gutters">
		<legend>Where are you?</legend>
		<div class="unit size1of2">
			<label for="city">City</label>
			<input type="text" id="city">
		</div>
		<div class="lastUnit">
			<label for="state">State</label>
			<select>
				<option>New York</option>
				<option>New Jersey</option>
				<option>New Mexico</option>
				<option>New Oregon</option>
			</select>
		</div>
	</fieldset>

	<label for="unicorn">Describe your unicorn</label>
	<textarea name="unicorn"></textarea>
</form>

Checkboxes and radio sets

Checkbox and radio inputs are placed inside the <label> elements for larger click targets.

The default label size applies here, but you can add a .small modifier to the labels if you prefer something smaller

<input type="checkbox" />, <input type="radio" />

I'm interested in... 
 <form>
	<fieldset>
		<legend>I'm interested in...</legend>
		<label class="small"><input type="checkbox" /> Cats</label>
		<label class="small"><input type="checkbox" checked="checked" /> Honey Badgers</label>
		<label class="small"><input type="checkbox" /> Quails</label>
		<label class="small"><input type="checkbox" checked="checked" /> Goats</label>
		<label class="small"><input type="checkbox"  checked="checked" /> Red Pandas</label>
	</fieldset>
</form>

Form field sizes

There are width helpers defined in layout.scss that can assist in changing the default width of fields. You can ajust the width by thirds and quarters of the width of the parent container.

.span-25, .span-30, .span-50, .span-60, .span-75

.span-25 .span-30 .span-50 .span-60 .span-75 .span-100 Default (width: auto;)

Error states

.error

You are not Keith Hernandez.

Disabled elements

.disabled, <input ... disabled />, <input ... disabled="disabled" />
